column9: TEXT
Ladies and gentlemen, good afternoon.
Welcome to analysts' briefing of Sun Hung Kai Properties interim results 2012/2013.
The briefing will start with a summary on the interim results and the business review.
We will then open the floor for question and answer session.
The presenters today are Mr. Patrick Chan, Exec Director and Chief Financial Officer of Sun Hung Kai Properties, and Mr. Brian Sum, Senior Manager, Corporate Planning.
May I now invite Mr. Patrick Chan to get start?
Mr. Chan, please.
Good afternoon ladies and gentlemen.
Thank you for taking time out of your busy schedule to attend SHKP's FY 2013 interim results announcement today.
Before I start I actually would like to wish you all an invigorating forward momentum in the year of snake, as busy as possible.
In the next 15 to 20 minutes Brian and I will present the interim results and the future outlook for the Group.

As usual I will share with you the financial highlights and Brian will give you updates on our business operations, following which I will also talk about the Group's prospects going forward and then we'll open the floor to your questions.
Would that be alright to you?
I'll first go through with you some of the financial indicators.
Let's start with a snapshot of the key numbers.
Please note all figures are in Hong Kong dollars.
The reported net profit was HKD22.5b, up 7% year on year for the six months ended December 31, 2012.
The reported earnings per share increased to HKD8.6 at 5%.

On the other hand, underlying net profit excluding the fair value changes of investment properties net of deferred taxation and non-controlling interests, decreased slightly by 2% year on year to HKD11.5b.
And the underlying earnings per share was HKD4.41.
The interim dividend per share was HKD0.95, the same as for the corresponding period last year.
Moving on, to have a close-up of the profit we'll break down by segment as follows.
Rental income and property sales, especially those generated from Hong Kong, remained the main contributors to our bottom line.

Net rental income grew by 11% year-on-year to HKD5,835m, which was mainly due to positive rental reversions and high rents of new leases of shopping mall and office portfolios, whereas the profit of property sales declined by 19% year on year to HKD6,408m which was a result of having less luxury projects booked during the period under review.
You may remember the Imperial Cullinan was actually booked in last corresponding period.
The profits of Hotel operations registered a year-on-year decrease of 10% to HKD506m.

However, excluding the Royal Plaza, which is currently under renovation, and one-off pre-opening expenses for Crowne Plaza and Holiday Inn Express, the Hotel operations in fact experienced a 20% growth as compared to the same period last year.
Other businesses including telecommunications and information technology and infrastructure accounted for a total of HKD1,818m, representing a 5% year-on-year increase.
All these figures added up to the Group's total segmental profit of HKD14,567m, down 6% year on year for the period ended December 31, 2012.
As at December 31, 2012 the Group's gearing ratio was 16.5%.
Shareholders' funds and net debt stood at HKD368,302m and HKD60,614m respectively.
For the first half of FY 2013 the interest cover remains comfortable at 10.4 times.
I'll now pass the time on to Brian to give you a business review of our business operations in Hong Kong and on the Mainland.
Thank you Patrick.
Let me start with an overview of our business in Hong Kong first.

As at December 2012 the Group held more than 46m square feet in its Hong Kong land bank of which over 28m square feet is completed investment properties and around 18m square feet is property under development.
On top of that we own 27m square feet of farmland in terms of site area.
And you can see from the charts on your left that around 80% of the property under development is for residential purpose.
On the right, of the Group completed investment properties, 37% is shopping centers, 35% is offices and the rest includes hotels, industrial buildings etc.
Concerning the Group's land bank, we have acquired four new sites for the period under review.
These four sites, as shown in the table, together have an attributable gross floor area over 1.4m square feet and the majority of the units to be built will be small to medium-sized units.
The newly acquired sites include a prime site in North Point.
This site has a wide seafront overlooking Victoria Harbor.
Other prime sites are the waterfront site at Area 66D2 in Tseung Kwan O acquired in November last year and two redevelopment sites in rapidly changing Island West.
Now I would like to turn to Hong Kong property investment.
The Group is one of the major landlords in Hong Kong, owning a well-diversified shopping malls and offices across Hong Kong and serving a wide range of tenants.

And the Group's commitments to building quality, premium service and continuous upgrading has established a strong and long-lasting relationship with its tenants and is the preferred choice of their business expansion and relocation.
For the period under review the Group's gross rental income grew by 10% mainly driven by higher rents for new leases and renewals.
For the past four years the gross rental income CAGR was 10%, showing strong recurrent income with sustained growth.
On the right you can see from the pie chart that shopping centers make up over one half of the total rental income in Hong Kong.
Offices contribute more than one third.
The overall occupancy rate remain high at around 95% and we continue to see positive rental reversion.
Looking at the Group's retail portfolio, for the six months ended 2012 the Group achieved over HKD3.2b of gross rental income, which is 8% higher than the last corresponding period.
Currently the Group owns an extensive network of shopping mall across different regions in Hong Kong with over 10m square feet of retail space.
The majority of the malls are located in densely populated districts and close to railway, serving both local consumer and tourist.
Occupancy remained high and sales growth of our tenants in major malls was above the market average.
In order to bring a fresher shopping experience, the Group consistently upgrades and renovates its malls.
Grand Central Place above MTR Mong Kok East station is a current example of such renovation.
The Group continues to expand its retail network in Hong Kong.
In the near term V City atop MTR Tuen Mun station is expected to begin operations later this year.
The retail space is almost fully pre-leased and most of the trade names is new to Tuen Mun.
In the medium term the Group is developing a 1m square foot regional mall in Yuen Long called YOHO mall and a nearly 300,000 square foot premium shopping mall at MTR Nam Cheong station.
This new mall will further enhance the scale and diversity of the Group's retail networks in Hong Kong.
Next turning to the Group's diverse office portfolio.
For the period under review the gross rental income from office portfolio grew 15% to HKD2.2b mainly driven by higher rents on renewals.
Overall occupancy remained high.
Currently the Group holds over 10m square feet of office space in Hong Kong and the majority is well-connected to railways and located in non-central areas where demand remains strong.
The leasing market in Central remained relatively steady amidst the uncertain global economy and the two first-class office towers at IFC maintained their leading positions in Central.
Now moving on to the Group's property development in Hong Kong, for the period under review the Group has booked around HKD14b in property sales with satisfactory development margin.
Major projects booked in the period include Century Gateway Phase 1 in Tuen Mun, the KCC Tower B in Kwai Chung and Elite Centre in Kwun Tong.
Regarding property completions in Hong Kong, the Group completed four projects with over 1.8m square feet of attributable GFA of which more than half was residential.
For the second half of this financial year the Group plans to complete one project which is a 120,000 square foot office buildings in Kwun Tong.
Looking at contracted sales mix in Hong Kong the Group achieved HKD11b during the period under review.
The major new project launched was the first phase of Century Gateway which received a strong response from buyers in September 2012.
Since the beginning of this year the Group has already achieved impressive contracted sales of nearly HKD9b.
the major new launches includes the Wings II in Tseung Kwan O and the Residence 88 in Yuen Long.
Wings II located in the well-planned Tseung Kwan O town center with comprehensive facilities has been well-received by the buyers with over 95% of the units sold already.
Two weeks ago, right after Chinese New Year the Group launched Residence 88, a low-density residential project in Yuen Long.
So far over 60% of the units were sold already.

Following the recent launches, major upcoming residential projects for sale in the coming months will include a luxury project in Imperial Kennedy in Island West, RIVA, a low-density project in Yuen Long, Phase 2 of Century Gateway and a premium project in Fanling.
Let me talk about the Group's development on the Mainland.

As at December 2012 the Group held more than 82m square feet of land bank on the Mainland of which around 73m square feet is properties under development and 9.5m square feet is completed investment properties.
On your left you can see from the chart that of properties under development, around 77% is for residential purpose.
On the right, of completed investment properties over one-half is shopping centers, another one-third is offices and the rest includes hotels and residential units.

Moving on to the Group's Mainland property investment, rental income from Mainland investment properties has increased significantly in the past few years and has become a notable contributor to the Group's rental business.
For the period under review the gross rental income rose by 33% to close to HKD1b.
The sharp growth was mainly driven by high rents for new leases and the full half year impact from new investment properties such as Shanghai ICC's first office tower.

Looking at Shanghai IFC in Pudong, one of the Group's flagship buildings on the Mainland, the success of this project has demonstrated the Group's ability to develop large-scale integrated complexes and helped boost the Group's brand recognition on the Mainland.
The first office tower in Shanghai IFC is fully occupied while occupancy of the second tower is on the rise.
Meanwhile the traffic flow in the Shanghai IFC mall continues to increase.
A new second phase has opened and both phases of over 1.2m square feet of retail space have been fully let.
On the opposite side of the Huangpu river is Shanghai ICC, another of the Group's flagship integrated projects.
The first office tower has achieved high occupancy while second office tower is currently under construction and expected to be completed in 2015.
IAPM at ICC will provide 1.3m retail space on Huai Hai Zhong Road, a popular shopping district in Puxi, Shanghai.
It is scheduled to open by mid of 2013 and has been almost fully pre-leased.
Going forward the Group will continue to build its retail network in prime cities on the Mainland.
The 50% owned Hong Cheng retail project near Tienhe metro station in Guangzhou will provide nearly 900,000 square feet of retail space and is expected to commence operations in 2015.
The 35% owned integrated Minhang project will comprise of 1.5m square feet of regional shopping mall located in Xinzhuang Station in Shanghai.
Moving on to the Mainland property development, the Group has booked around HKD3b property sales for the period under review.
Major projects booked include Taihu International Community in Wuxi, the Riviera and Lake Dragon both in Guangzhou.
For the period under review the Group completed an attributable 1.6m square feet of properties located in Guangzhou and Wuxi.
For the second half of this financial year the Group plans to complete 1.3m square feet of properties of which about 200,000 square feet at Shanghai ICC Residence is then intended for rent.
Looking at the contracted sales on the Mainland, the Group achieved over HKD4b of sales for the period under review.

Major projects sold include the wholly-owned Shanghai Arch, 33% owned Riviera in Guangzhou and the 70% owned Forest Hills in the luxury area in Tianhe district, Guangzhou which was launched in December last year.
And since the beginning of this year the Group has achieved an additional HKD1.4b in contracted sales on the Mainland.
A major new project sold was upper MIXC, a serviced apartment in Hangzhou.

In the coming months we shall launch several projects including the 40% owned first phase of Foothill Residence in the popular luxury residential district in Zhijiang in Hangzhou, the second batch of Forest Hills in Tianhe district and new phase of Park Royale both in Guangzhou.
Lastly let me talk about the performance of Hotel operations.
The Group's hotel portfolio continued to perform satisfactorily.
The occupancy rates on a room available basis remained very high and room's rates continued to rise.
Crowne Plaza and Holiday Inn Express which opened last year are operating smoothly.
Revenue grew strongly in the past four years with CAGR of 23%.

However the operating profits was slower for this period mainly due to over 300,000 rooms in Royal Plaza located in Mong Kok were being renovated and there was some pre-opening expenses for the Crowne Plaza and Holiday Inn Express.
That concludes what I would like to say.
Now I would like to pass to Patrick to discuss the Group's strategy and prospects.
Thank you Brian.
Prior to our going through the Group's strategies and prospects, I would like to touch upon our views on the market for sharing.

The global and Mainland economies are expected to see improvement in 2013, upheld by a recovering US housing sector, loose monetary policies with low interest rates and expanded quantitative easing programs of major central banks globally, as well as the commitment to continue with urbanization, economic reform and the infrastructure upgrades in Mainland China.
It is anticipated that Hong Kong's economy will pick up modestly in tandem with the improved economic growth on the Mainland.
Improving Mainland economy is a contributory factor to the sustainable development of its property markets, and the Group remains confident in the Mainland's prospects in the long term.

Hong Kong's property sector will continue to be in favor of its healthy domestic consumption, solid infrastructure investment, low mortgage rates, continuous income growth and its role as an international financial hub, amidst various government measures in place.
Nonetheless, in view of the latest measures we have decided to revise the Group's full year contracted sales target for FY 2013 downwards to HKD32b from HKD35b that we said in September last year.
I am going to highlight the following to split up the Group's well-established business strategy which I'm sure you're fully aware of.
To achieve a balance in income from property sales and investment properties.
To foster the Group's brand appeal by virtue of providing high-quality products and excellent services.
To adhere to a selective and focused approach to investments on the Mainland.
Last but not the least, to adhere to the prudent financial management discipline.
Proceeding to the Group's business prospects, I will first give you some color on our investment portfolio.
Rental income, which is one of our growth engines, will continue to benefit from the following.
Number one is sustained high occupancies, secondly positive rental reversions, followed by contribution from new additions of investment properties such as V City in Tuen Mun and IAPM in Shanghai.

Last but not the least continuous value enhancement in terms of tenant and trade mix and meaningful growth [with -- to come] from developing new investment properties on the Mainland in the medium term.
In respect of property sales, the Group as always pursues the delivery of premium products to meet customer needs well supported by a land bank sufficient for development in the next five years.

In order to strengthening its property development business for sale over the long term, the Group will continue to, number one, focus on providing well-designed flat mixes, particularly small to medium-sized flats.
Secondly, offer new projects of high quality of sale and also look for good land acquisition opportunity to replenish its land bank.
Ladies and gentlemen, this come to an end of our presentation and --
Before we continue, I'd like to introduce to you our panel.

From your left, Mr. Brian Sum, whom you have already met, Senior Manager, Corporate Planning of Sun Hung Kai Properties; Mr. Alfred So, Executive Director of Sun Hung Kai Real Estate Agency; Mr. Victor Lui, Deputy Managing Director of Sun Hong Kai Properties; Mr. Patrick Chan, whom you have already met, Exec Director and Chief Financial Officer of Sun Hung Kai Properties; Mr. Raymond Kwok, Chairman and Managing Director of Sun Hong Kai Properties; Mr. Thomas Kwok, Chairman and Managing Director of Sun Hong Kai Properties; Mr. Thomas Chan, Executive Director of Sun Hong Kai Properties.
Mr. Mike Wong, Deputy Managing Director of Sun Hong Kai Properties; and Mr. Eric Chow, Executive Director of Sun Hong Kai Real Estate Agency.
The question and answer session will now begin.
Please state now for the microphone, if you would like to ask a question, and speak clearly for our webcast.
Video of today's briefing will be uploaded on our corporate website.
Also, please identify yourself and the name of your company before starting your question.
Yes, on my left, lady in the second row.
Perveen Wong from HSBC.

Given the ongoing policy announcements and the potential interruptions to the physical market, does the Company have any alternative plans to make sure that the contracted sales target, which has now been revised, that it will be met?
For example, would the Company considering --- consider selling more commercial properties or accelerating sales on the China front?

Apart from the Wings II that we just launched with overwhelming response, within a few weeks time the project was almost sold out and following will be the Residence 88 which is also well received and also our Hong Kong Island Project, Imperial Kennedy, plus our low-density luxury project, you know is RIVA.
In the middle of the year there will be Phase 2 of Century Gateway and lastly will be the premium building in Fanling at the end of the year.
And apart from the residential projects we are also planning to launch the office project in [Hung To] Road, Kwun Tong later this year.

And in fact in the past few years we are also disposing a number of non-core investment properties including office projects, retail premises, some under construction and some under tenancies, and a number of luxury residential units.
Given that investment sentiment continues to be very strong and we shall continue to offload some of our non-core investment properties in the coming two years.

And overall we are very busy on launching our new projects and selling out properties in this year, but given that new measures will affect the transaction of the residential market, we have to slightly adjust downwards our sales target to HKD32b in this financial year.
Gentleman at the back.
Cusson Leung from Credit Suisse.
I first just want to see what's the management view on the latest change of the government land sales method to regular auction.
And I think secondly is relating to the land banking in China.
Is there any plan or is there a business strategy to try to accelerate the land banking in China again?
Well we are still very confident about the long term prospects of the property market on the Mainland.
We will keep looking for prime sites with good locations and we will be selective in our new acquisition.
Selective means we will be only buying sites that is close, that are close to, for example, mass transit stations.
We are particularly interested in integrated projects for which I think we can make the best use of our expertise.

The announcement by Government just now, one hour ago on the change of land sales, I think that's good, that's good for Hong Kong because in the long run you need certainty, certainty of the land supply etc., etc. so that we can also plan our acquisition plan.
I believe the -- actually on the residential side I think our strategy is to replenish our land back that have been sold.

So basically probably we are going to increase our land acquisition to make up for the loss of profit margin because of construction cost, because of more stable property prices, meaning we need to do the (inaudible).
And on the commercial and meeting office, shopping centers, hotels, we can see there the supply is still very limited for the next four years.
And I see the rental growth, as Patrick has done in the presentation, that's our overall rental will be a positive.
And we are confident on the investment income side.
On the property development, I think as I said, we need to do more, more production to get more land from the land auction or tender.
In terms of human resources is concerned, we are better off because we have our own construction which we confidently can increase the production.
Yes, right now people talking about the land supply, but actually the challenges are construction labor, construction professional.
They are in huge shortage, not like the investment banks, I must say.
I understand your dilemma.
But in the construction and development industry it's so shortage.
It's so short of professional, every types of the construction ladder, either in construction site or in the design work.
I've never seen anything like this for the last 34 years.
Gentleman on the second row.
Okay, lady at the back.
I'm [Karen Kwong] from [Maybank].
Can you give us the breakdown between Hong Kong and China for your HKD32b property sales target?
And also recently we've seen your Chengdu ICC and Forest Hill projects in China having higher prices than initially launched.
So what price assumptions do you expect for China over the next year?
And the other question is about farmland.
How much farmland conversion do you expect to be successfully converted over the next 12 months?
We have revised our contract sales targets upwards on the Mainland from the original HKD7b to HKD9.8b.
There's also a question on the conversion of agricultural land, right?
So we are still negotiating with government on several lots so hopefully we can negotiate the right premium with the government.
We're still under negotiation.
Anthony Wu, Goldman Sachs.
I actually found this target a bit interesting because you already achieved HKD25b year to date, actually since July last year.
And now with the revised target for China that imply, if my calculation is correct, you are going to achieve another HKD4b/HKD5b sales in China for the remainder of the fiscal year.
And then you still, you have HKD7b to reach the full target of HKD32b.
So you are telling me that you're going to achieve HKD2b.
We are used to being a little bit more conservative, alright.
Yes, I know your question --
It's only HKD2b for Hong Kong.
We are a little bit conservative.
But now on the other hand China, we are a little bit more aggressive.
I'm sure you know the number.
I'm pretty sure that you can actually easily achieve HKD2b sales in Hong Kong in the next four months.
So we will compare the notes six months later.
And on the China side, we have seen a quite a number of successful cases in your development in the past six/seven years, Shanghai IFC, Shanghai ICC.

Now with very good experience and also good amount of knowledge built up over the last six/seven years, would it be too aggressive if we expect you to expand a little bit more in China in the next few years?
I think we will, honestly, but right now cities like Beijing, Shanghai, Hangzhou, will be our major focus, major focus for expansion.
We talk about investment properties we are going to build in Shanghai, in Nanjing, in Chengdu and also in Hangzhou, quite a bit in Hangzhou.

It is hard to say/commit a figure, but we are going to expand in China, but gradually at our price, at our price which we think is reasonable because at the same time we've got to compare where the return.
Now the land is more available in Hong Kong now, we have to balance.
And also we have some, I believe it's at least about 5,000-plus under negotiation with the Government on land, farmland conversion.
So we have to balance.
Okay, 20% completement, it's only a benchmark.
It depends on opportunities offered on the table.
Right now it's clear that a lot more opportunities are now in Hong Kong and we have to do a little bit more.
So the choices are there.
So every time --- but the capital is so --- it's only that much.
So basically we have to balance on our capital and also our human resources and strengths in Hong Kong and China, especially in Hong Kong.
I know from reading your analyses very few of investment banks concerned about the capacity.
Construction capacity is a very difficult subject right now.
It's a --- I would say apart from land supply it would be the second most difficult issue to handle.
[Sid Kenyon] from Citi.
I have questions on FY '13 earnings.
You just have one project to complete in the second half of this financial year, Sun Yip Street, which is a commercial project.
Are you going to relaunch some of the unsold inventory, like Cullinan or the Shouson Peak project or the 12 houses at the Peak to make up the profit in the second half of the year versus last year?
For the Cullinan Project I think we all know that the sales have been overwhelming in the past.
And for the first tower we have already sold over 500 units and actually we only have 100 units left.
We have very high hope on this project and in last year we have done a record price here by selling one unit at HKD50,000 per square foot, which is a record price in the whole Kowloon Station.
And as for Cullinan II, which is attaching to the public hotel, we are doing the upgrading works now and we are ready for disposal later this year.
Eugene from UBS.
Just got two questions.
First, you mentioned about the different environment right now with more consistence of supply of land, but at the same time construction costs going up.
So what would your expectation on your land replenishment and how has it been changing in the past five years, five years ago, say?
And also would you --- you mentioned about you will be increasing your production and increasing your market share potentially.
Would you tolerate a higher gearing level as a result?
Higher what?
Higher gearing tolerance level as a result.

And also the second question is given that the government has been releasing a lot of land, but at the same time a lot of unit-size restriction, and the same time the policy is also very targeted on big unit demands basically, so how would you balance your portfolio with end users against investors, or bigger units against smaller units?
Well, I can only answer you, it's a very fluid situation, but we monitor our gearing pretty well.
So your gearing is, up to a certain point, we would just stop.
And right now we are gearing, it's about 16.5%, so we still have a lot of room.
And we have close to HKD20b sales receipts coming in the next two years.
So we're not pessimistic about the market.
We are just saying that the long-term potential are still there.
Talk about the Asia or Asian growth, China etc. etc, e need to do more.
We need to maintain our market share, which is roughly about 20%.
So if the total flat supply is around 20,000 flats per annum, let's say in next four, in four years time, we need to do something like 4,000 units.
And right now we produce around 3,000.
That's a lot of room to grow.
So are we going to do more?
Are we going to expand in China?
Are we going to increase our gearing?
Probably not.
Due to the time schedule I would like to invite two more questions.
Lady on fourth row.
Lucia Kwong from JP Morgan.
Two questions.
The government is also releasing land, commercial land sites for developers, for future investment opportunities.
Between Hong Kong residential and Hong Kong commercial, which part do you see more investment potential?
And the second question is on the dividend policy.
We see that both China and Hong Kong market will have a lot of tightening or policy measure interventions on the residential market and that may bring future earnings volatility.
Would management consider to restrict the dividend policy to paying an absolute dividend amount instead of based on the pay-out ratio?
Okay, thank you, thank you boss.
I don't think we have any plans at the moment to change our dividend policy.
So I hope that will comfort you.

To respond to you on the commercial versus residential, I think we have a good --- we have strong teams in office development and also in residential, and we welcome government to release more land on the office side.
In a way the more land being supplied, the more opportunities for us.
I think we equally welcome supply in office and also residential.
The last question please.
Gentleman on the second row.
Sorry.
Anthony Wu from Goldman Sachs again.

When I look at your financial statements simply looking at the consolidated investment properties, which is about HKD250b worth, and rough estimate of IFC and the associated line, you can -- added back, you can come up with easily over HKD100 per share in fixed income --- in fixed asset or investment properties.
The share prices of Sun Hung Kai is now trading at HKD1.20, which is --
You're talking about a split?

No.  We don't have investment banker here, but I'm just curious about any thought on taking any actions to unlock the value, to make the share price more fairly reflect the value of your investment property portfolio.
We have no such intention because I think with good analysts like you, your readers should be able to understand that we are very strong on the investment property side.
So maybe hopefully you do more writing to explain to the investors that we do have a very good investment property portfolio.
And, as Thomas said, the rental income will go up over time because clearly we know from our rental reversion that the rental on the office and on the retail front is going up, yes.
Thank you very much.
This will be the final question since we have already run out of time.
The briefing is coming to close.
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for coming and hope you found the briefing informative.
There's some refreshments outside.
Please stay and enjoy.
Thank you very much.
